HISTORY OF THE CITY

Mauritius and its capital city, Port Louis, are closely linked in history. Port Louis was chosen, as from 1732, to be the port of the then Ile de France (former name of Mauritius). This was the ideal choice as Port Louis had the characteristics of a natural harbour with a strategic position in the Indian Ocean.

Bertrand FranÃ§ois MahÃ© de Labourdonnais, first governor of Mauritius, started the construction of Port Louis in 1735.

Port Louis has the credit of being the birthplace of regional democracy in Mauritius, one century before the legislative assembly was created. The first municipality in the island was established in Port Louis in 1790 during the period of the French revolution. When General Decaen took over as governor of the island in 1803, the town was named as âPort NapolÃ©onâ. In 1810 when the island became British colony, Governor Robert Farquhar gave back its original name of Port Louis to the town. The municipal administration, established during the French period and abolished in 1803, was replaced by a district administration.
